content.text: A new Eliza plugin for Obsidian, developed by @XCodeCarlos, transforms an Obsidian vault into an AI agent, functioning as a digital librarian for social interactions.
A bug fix was implemented for the SttTtsPlugin in the Eliza framework, addressing an issue related to missing names and descriptions.
Unused imports were removed from the plugin-twitter module to improve code efficiency.

A new Akash Network plugin was introduced, enabling Eliza to autonomously manage decentralized cloud computing resources, including deployment management, provider interaction, and resource allocation.
A new plugin, NillionDB, was added along with a fix for the LensPlugin export.
A syntax issue in the Autonome plugin was fixed, along with an update to the lock file.
A previous change (#1808) was reverted due to conflicting environment variables, and a missing import for the CoinGecko plugin was added.
Improvements were made to the plugin loading mechanism from character.json files, ensuring better compatibility and support for missing plugins.
A Lens Network plugin was introduced, allowing users to transfer Grass tokens on the Lens Testnet.
A new Solana web3.js V2 plugin was added, along with automated liquidity provisioning (LPing) on Orca, enabling autonomous repositioning of liquidity positions.
The web search plugin was updated to use google.serper.dev for improved search functionality.
A StakeWise plugin was introduced, allowing Eliza to fetch and validate APY and TVL data for StakeWise vaults.
A new CKB Fiber plugin was added, enabling Eliza to interact with the Fiber Network for stablecoin payments using the Lightning Network.
A Quai Network plugin was introduced, allowing Eliza to perform native QUAI token transfers and secure transaction signing.
A new Code In plugin was introduced, allowing Eliza characters to be stored permanently on the blockchain using IQ6900's inscription standard.
A simple 'Dad Jokes' plugin was created for development purposes, helping new developers understand provider and evaluator concepts.
A discussion was started regarding long-term memory for the Telegram client, exploring ways to retain information beyond recent messages.

The latest cryptocurrency prices show fluctuations across major assets. Wrapped Bitcoin (WBTC) saw an increase from $92,397.02 to $94,611.67. Wrapped Ethereum (WETH) also experienced a rise from $3,218.77 to $3,267.18. Solana (SOL) moved up from $184.95 to $187.65. However, ai16z saw a slight decline from $1.42 to $1.39.

categories.title: Recent Updates and Bounties in Tech Support and AI Features

content.text: A bounty may still be available for assistance with RuneScape support. Users are discussing potential help and checking on progress.

Multiple updates have been made to support the Autonome platform using Eliza. These updates introduce new environments and authentication methods, allowing users to log in and interact with the platform more efficiently.
A new feature has been added to support image vision using Google's Gemini. This update refactors the image vision provider, making it easier to extend and integrate with different AI models.
Twitter photo support has been added, enhancing the platform's ability to handle and process images shared on Twitter.

A new Text-to-Speech (TTS) feature has been introduced, supporting over 15 languages including English, Korean, Japanese, Spanish, German, and Russian. This enhancement improves AI-driven voice interactions.
Developers are exploring new ways to combine plugins, with some believing that certain plugins pair well together for enhanced functionality.

The plugin ecosystem is still in its early stages, with most developers only utilizing a few plugins at a time. There is significant potential for composing multiple plugins together in innovative ways.

The number of available plugins has grown significantly, with 46 core plugins and 5 adaptor plugins, totaling 51. There is growing interest in integrating a majority of these plugins to create more advanced automation and agent capabilities.

A proposal has been made to refactor the wallet provider by separating data providers into plugins. This would improve maintainability, testing, and flexibility by allowing users to choose their preferred data sources.
A major change has been proposed to move all plugins from the main monorepo to a dedicated community plugins repository. This aims to reduce dependency bloat and improve maintainability.

Development efforts have focused on package improvements, including the addition of an Akash Network plugin with autonomous deployment capabilities, along with 8 bug fixes and contributions from 40 developers across 16 merged PRs.

categories.title: Discussion on Technical Assistance and Misleading Information

content.text: @solarnius @piotreksol üñêÔ∏èüò≥ü§ö ya got me checking out the repo lmk how we can help
@JW100x I think you're misleading with your original post tho

A chat transcript was analyzed, but it contained minimal substantive content. The only notable message was from [yikesawjeez] asking about adding a bot to their server, but no responses were recorded. No significant technical discussions, problem-solving, or action items were present.
Crypto is fundamentally about incentive alignment engineering, with tokens serving as the core primitives. Without understanding this, one cannot fully grasp the essence of the industry.
Many crypto founders have backgrounds in online gaming, leading guilds, and engaging with hacker communities. These experiences often shape their approach to building in the crypto space.

Crypto development is progressing rapidly, and while challenges exist, developers are continuously working on solutions. It is likely that someone is already tackling current issues despite facing obstacles.
For crypto analytics, learning SQL or hiring someone to create a dashboard on Flipside Crypto can be beneficial.

categories.title: Comparison of GitHub Activity: Eliza vs. BabyAGI

content.text: A quick analysis of the Eliza and BabyAGI GitHub repositories highlights key differences in activity and engagement. Eliza has seen recent development with a last commit just 7 minutes ago, 167 open issues, 136 open pull requests, and 173 merged this week. It has 10.9k stars and 2.9k forks, indicating strong engagement and active development.

In contrast, BabyAGI has significantly more stars (20k) but much lower development activity. The last commit was two months ago, with only 13 commits in total. It has 6 open issues and 3 pull requests, suggesting lower engagement compared to Eliza. While stars indicate interest, forks, pull requests, and issues are better indicators of active contribution and development.
A broader discussion highlights that GitHub stars alone are not a reliable metric for assessing a project's health. More nuanced tools are needed to analyze repository activity effectively.

categories.title: Recent Enhancements and Fixes in ElizaOS

content.text: A new embedding model provider, Heurist, has been added to ElizaOS. This integration introduces the BAAI/bge-large-en-v1.5 model as the default, supporting 1024-dimension vectors. The update also includes remote embedding functionality and updates to model configurations, such as meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct and FLUX.1-dev. Documentation updates are required to reflect these changes, and new environment variables must be configured for deployment.

A fix has been applied to ensure model settings for images are correctly implemented and to remove duplicate files. The update addresses an issue where duplicate files were uploaded in a previous pull request. Additionally, Infera-related code will be moved to the correct files.

Mistral AI has been added as a new model provider in ElizaOS. This integration includes support for text and object generation using the @ai-sdk/mistral package. The update introduces environment variables for model selection and ensures proper error handling and response parsing. Documentation updates are required, and new environment variables must be configured for deployment.

categories.title: README File Updates and Fixes in elizaOS/eliza

content.text: A duplicate README file was found in the 'packages/plugin-story' directory of the elizaOS/eliza repository. This caused a warning when cloning the repository on MacOS. The issue was reported in GitHub Issue #2104.

A fix was implemented in Pull Request #2105 to remove the duplicate README file, resolving the warning issue. The change was classified as a non-breaking bug fix with no documentation updates required.

Additionally, a new Portuguese version of the README file (README_PT.md) was added to the documentation section in Pull Request #2088. This update aims to improve accessibility for Portuguese-speaking developers.

A recent update optimizes memory fetching by moving sorting and slicing logic to the database layer, significantly improving query performance. The change reduces query execution time from 40 seconds to 0.02 seconds for large datasets. The update introduces an optional `limit` parameter and ensures that sorting (`createdAt DESC`) is handled at the database level. These improvements primarily affect the PostgreSQL adapter but do not introduce breaking changes for other database adapters.

Another update addresses issues with Supabase database interactions, preventing errors caused by missing rooms and mixed-case column names. The `getRoom()` function now uses `.maybeSingle()` instead of `.single()`, preventing crashes when a room is not found. Additionally, database seed values have been updated to include valid timestamps and required non-null fields. These changes improve database robustness without modifying fundamental logic.
